title: What's the quickest way to learn Arabic? - Quora

response.answer_text: Your motivation to learn languages is awesome, and I was in a similar boat when I was in high school some years ago! I have a history of being on the patient-end of speech therapy, so I prefer to learn from an instructor in a classroom or office environment. My suggestion would be to do some quick Web searches of local community colleges to see if they offer classes. Another place I’ve found classes offered are businesses operated by folks of Arab origin or descent; I live close to a vegan restaurant owned by a Syrian man who teaches classes with the Alif Baa and al-Kitaab textbook series. I suppose that’s a logical segue onto the topic of books. In Penn State’s Arabic program, they use the Alif Baa for the introductory course and move on the first and second parts of al-Kitaab. Problem is that these books are not particularly cheap - even if they’re used. If you’re willing to deal with some dull, institutional writing characteristic of US Government publications, the Defense Language Institute, Foreign Service Institute, and Peace Corps have produced language guides which can be accessed for free, as they are in the public domain. I found these on LiveLingua[1], but they can likely be found elsewhere. This medium naturally don’t cover speaking, which is where videos and audio comes in. YouTube ends up being an awesome asset here; there are playlists and occasionally full Arabic movies. There’s “Short Arabic dialogue for beginners[2]” as well as the “CERCLL Native Speakers Series[3],” both of which feature offer some insight into Arab culture. You can also find movies on YouTube with ease, though they’re probably “vintage” at this point, as in “a ton of movies from the seventies.” More recent films of note include Wadjda, about a young schoolgirl in Saudi Arabia, and Theeb, which is centered around a young Bedouin boy in modern-day Jordan during the First World War. I hope these resources can hold you over until you can interact with some native speakers. Arabic is, like you said, a truly beautiful language, and - perhaps more importantly - allow you to communicate with many other people and better understand what’s occurring in the world. Footnotes[1] Peace Corps Language Courses[2] Short Arabic dialogue for beginners[3] CERCLL Native Speakers Series

Learn the alphabets. Learn vowels like Fatha, Dhamma, Kasra & Sukun, etc. search for Arabic alphabet on google search and click for image on the search result. You will see plenty of image lists.Understand the Arabic culture. Read on Wikipedia, possibly search on youtube.If you are living in middle east, listen to local Arabic radio/ TV channel to learn common words. Its better if the TV channel offers English Subtitles. With this method you can start reading hoardings, traffic signs, newspaper advertisement, display boards.Go to Youtube and learn most common words from different Youtuber’s Channels.Go on various website which teach arabic. google for “Arabic words”, Arabic numers”, “Fruit names in arabic”, etcUnderstand There are different arabic dialects, accents like Khaleej (Gulf countries), Egyptian, Lebanese, Syrian, etc. Note there are difference between each gulf countries too, however you will surely catch on once you are accustomed to it.Speak with a friend, colleague, shop keeper, a native Arabic speaker if you can find one (if you are in Middle east), etc.Use google translator to translate English word in to Arabic to find transliteration (Romanization) and thereby its pronunciation. You can hear them too.Learn numbers at least 1 to 10, they are the easiest. Use google to search websites and youtube.Learn days of the week. Use google to search websites and youtube.Make a spreadsheet of Arabic, English words and keep memorizing it. Keep it in your mobile and use it when ever you need.Last but not least go to a professional Arabic classes, buy related books. You can be ready to learn grammar from 4 and 12.Note National of countries which are adjacent to middle east tend to share few words, culture and therefore tend to understand mutually used words better than nationals from complete alien countries like the european or americans. Example: Tazza - Means fresh in Arabic and also in Urdu, Hindi, etc. (as in fresh milk) Zahma - Means crowd or traffic in arabic means summing (+ to add) to existing in hindi. (although the pronunciation may be different). It also mean “to gather” in Marathi which is a language in Maharashtra state of India. From the same word Zahma you are infer Jummah in Arabic means Friday which is to gather for prayer comes.
